In 1971, Julian Tudor Hart proposed the inverse care law: “The availability of good medical care tends to vary inversely with the need for it in the population served.”
32 . An analogue of the inverse care law can be applied to public health and epidemiology. Expertise in these fields has traditionally gravitated towards centres of excellence in Europe and the United States. Of course, high-income countries are not immune to the disruption associated with epidemics, especially in an era of misinformation and growing mistrust in authorities and public health initiatives. However, the centre of gravity must shift so that globally representative distributed networks of collaborating centres can jointly ensure coverage in the regions that urgently need these skills on the ground
33 . International collaborations remain important; however, strengthening epidemiology, public health and laboratory capacity in low- and middle-income countries is essential
34 . Collaborative interventions should not be limited to when there is a major outbreak, but be integrated into regular interactions.
